editorialNotes.standard: No one would accuse PlaqueBoyMax of lacking creativity. The internet celebrity turned hip-hop curator made his first two EPs, 2025’s LONDON and ATLANTA, by traveling to those cities, recruiting local stars, and recording the entire projects during livestream events. Five Forever, his debut mixtape, strips away all the excess and attention-grabbing approaches to making an album. Without any features, Max takes center stage for the very first time, retiring his role as master of ceremonies and approaching the mic with the confidence of someone who’s been co-signed by many of the biggest names in the game. It’s clear that PlaqueBoy is heavily influenced by boundary-pushing rappers like Playboi Carti and Yeat, even embracing their use of clever one-liners and bass-heavy beats accented by glimmering, blown-out synths. On “Layflat,” he raps, “I only fly if it’s first class/I only fly if it’s lay-flat/Vivienne Westwood keychains/I do what I want and they hate that.” This may be Max’s first mixtape, but he is already deeply familiar with living the life of a superstar.
editorialNotes.short: A debut mixtape that strips away the excess.

editorialNotes.standard: For Summertime Sounds, the NY-based producer and DJ delivers an energetic mix of tracks—including some of his own—that’s perfect for a boat ride around Miami. “I chose these songs to best curate a bright, summery, high-energy Afro-house vibe that well balances commercial and underground flavors,” he tells Apple Music.
editorialNotes.short: The producer and DJ created a mix perfect for a boat ride around Miami.
The Edinburgh trio scores the zombie sequel with icy, eerie moods.

editorialNotes.standard: One of the more versatile collaborators in the current Latin music landscape, SAIKO has been sought out by everyone from J Balvin and Sech to Manuel Turizo and Mora. On 2024’s SAKURA, the Spanish artist showed his growing fanbase just how effective he can be when he’s the host rather than the guest, with album highlights like “BADGYAL” and “ESKELETO” making his case. Arriving a little over a year later, his moderately shorter follow-up NATSUKASHII YORU shows an emboldened SAIKO maximizing his moment and expanding his sonic breadth. Bookended by “SÍ QUIERO” and “NOSTALGIA,” two tracks that intentionally lean into the traditional, the rest of his 13-song set pushes forward with a futurist edge. That’s evident on the shimmering slowed dembow of “MIAMI 22,” the urgently pulsating electronica of “SAN JUAN,” and the progressive perreo of “WEKEWEKE.” Naturally, he’s invited some guests of his own along, setting his sights on some baddies with Omar Courtz on the thumping “LOKENECESITAS” and blissing out with Leire Martinez over the synth rock of “MARIPOSAS.”
editorialNotes.short: Nostalgia and futurism collide on this SAKURA follow-up.
Hardest. Darkest. Heaviest. Obey your master.

editorialNotes.standard: It’s hard to overstate SOPHIE’s influence on 21st-century pop. Pioneer, visionary, and an icon in music and beyond, the DJ, producer, and artist was as lauded by pop’s underground as its most mainstream artists—and the Glaswegian’s touch can be felt on almost everything in between. This is music that, somehow, channelled both the avant garde and a kind of blistering directness. Right from the start of the early 2010s, when SOPHIE emerged as a mystery-shrouded affiliate of experimental pop label PC Music, songs resisted musical boundaries. Rushing, hyperkinetic moments of ecstasy (“Immaterial”), glinting, metallic percussion (“Hard”), syncopated soda-bubble trap (“Lemonade”); whether through alien, synthesised effects or distorted snatches of robotic vocal, this former art school student brought a sculptor’s sensibility to candy-painted pop. But that didn’t mean subtlety and traditional musicianship weren’t present. 2018’s debut album Oil of Every Pearl’s Un-Insides broadened the scope, hurtling from the whispered torch song theatrics of “It’s Okay To Cry” to the smashed-glass, R&B gear-switches that give “Faceshopping” its urgent, convulsive energy. SOPHIE died January 30, 2021, at age 34.
